 My position is that the word "regulate[d]" has alternate meanings; granted, the ones I am claiming are obsolete now but they certainly were in common use and enjoyed a universal understanding in the Revolutionary period through the first half of the 19th century. 
 
 The acquisition of a comprehensive dictionary is important to this discussion because once we agree that regulate[d] has a specific and differentiated meaning when used to describe the condition of military corps, we can examine contemporaneous usage examples and apply critical thinking skills tempered with intellectual honesty, not political ideology.
 
 The Random House College Dictionary (1980) gives four definitions for the word "regulate."[*]regulate1) To control or direct by a rule, principle, method, etc. 
 
 2) To adjust to some standard or requirement as for amount, degree, etc. 
 
 3) To adjust so as to ensure accuracy of operation. 
 
 4) To put in good order. [obs.]b. Of troops: Properly disciplined. [Obs. rare] The past tense, "regulated" would then describe the performance / function of the troops after their training, displaying "good order" and "proper discipline." 
 
 So, as used in the 2nd Amendment, describing the militia, "well regulated" has nothing to do with any law or regulation.  BECAUSE
 
 "Well regulated" as used in the 2nd Amendment or when discussing military corps in general is an assessment of their function as a fighting unit and a characterization of their preparedness for battle; it means nothing more than said corps are in operational order and condition.

 "Ill" being the antonym of "well," I think it makes perfect sense.

Here are some of my thoughts (again) on the militia clause and the individual/collective right debate. Agree or disagree as you will....
 
 Our Constitution was born from a process of compromise between competing principles. The power to raise a standing army in time of need competed with the preference for reliance on militias: "that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty." (Constitution of Virginia, June 6, 1776). 
 
 Now look for a moment at the federal Constitution's broad grant of Congressional authority over both a standing army and the state militias (Art. I sec. 8):
 
 To raise and support armies, but no appropriation of money to that use shall be for a longer term than two years;
 To provide and maintain a navy;
 To make rules for the government and regulation of the land and naval forces;
 To provide for calling forth the militia to execute the laws of the Union, suppress insurrections and repel invasions;
 To provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining, the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States, reserving to the states respectively, the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress
 
 Consider also the proposed power of the president over both the army and the militias (Art. II sec. 2):
 
 The President shall be the commander in chief of the army and navy of the United States, and of the militia of the several states, when called into the actual service of the United States....
 
 Note that all of the state constitutions of the time maintained a public policy preference for militias over standing armies-while the federal Constitution was silent on this issue. Anti-federalists would not let the issue rest: 
 
 "It has been asserted by the most respectable writers upon government, that a well-regulated militia, composed of the yeomanry of the country, have ever been considered as the bulwark of a free people. Tyrants have never placed any confidence on a militia composed of freemen." John DeWitt, The Anti-Federalist Papers, p. 75 (M. Borden ed. 1965)
 
 The militia clause of the 2nd. Amendment-A well regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state-is in reality nothing more than a restatement of this principle. 
 
 How then do we best reach that goal? This was a question for our founders. A tremendous point of contention with the proposed federal Constitution was the grant of authority to congress over the militias. Hamilton argued that if you wanted to see this public policy goal become reality you must give Congress the power to make the militias a credible alternative to a standing army, including the ability to prescribe uniform arms, training, and discipline: 
 
 "This desirable uniformity can only be accomplished by confiding the regulation of the militia to the direction of the national authority. It is, therefore, with the most evident propriety, that the plan of the convention proposes to empower the Union to provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States, reserving to the states respectively the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by congress." Alexander Hamilton, Federalist #29.
 
 This is a key point to consider in the individual/state's right debate. If the 2nd. Amendment was intended to create a state's right, then by its very nature it destroys an efficient system of singular uniformity in favor of permitting the several states to arm their militias as they pleased, even to the point of making their weapons and equipment incompatible with one another. Such a system would serve only to encourage Congress to establish and rely upon a standing army. 
 
 Uniformity aside, however, a particular anti-federalist fear was that a federal tyrant might corrupt the militia. Hamilton ridiculed this fear and claimed the power of the states to appoint officers would prevent that fear from becoming reality: 
 
 "What reasonable cause of apprehension can be inferred from a power in the Union to prescribe regulations for the militia, and to command its services when necessary, while the particular States are to have the sole and exclusive appointment of the officers? If it were possible seriously to indulge a jealousy of the militia upon any conceivable establishment under the federal government, the circumstance of the officers being in the appointment of the States ought at once to extinguish it. There can be no doubt that this circumstance will always secure to them a preponderating influence over the militia." Id.
 
 But there was an even more serious rub for anti-federalists: Congress can create a standing army and then completely disarm the state militias simply by refusing to exercise its exclusive power to arm, train, and discipline them: 
 
 "Let me here call your attention to that part which gives the Congress power 'to provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States - reserving to the states, respectively, the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress.' By this, sir, you see that their control over our last and best defense is unlimited. If they neglect or refuse to discipline or arm our militia, they will be useless: the states can do neither - this power being exclusively given to Congress. The power of appointing officers over men not disciplined or armed is ridiculous; so that this pretended little remains of power left to the states may, at the pleasure of Congress, be rendered nugatory." Patrick Henry, Speech of June 5, 1788, before the Virginia Ratifying Convention, reprinted in The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates, beginning page 199, Mentor Books, 1986, edited by Ralph Ketchum. 
 
 The federalist response contains another key point to understanding the individual/state's right debate-it does not matter if Congress refuses to exercise its power to arm the militias because the public already enjoys an individual RKBA which will be an adequate check against a federal tyrant. Consider the following example: 
 
 "Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed; as they are in almost every kingdom of Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior to any bands of regular troops that can be, on any pretense, raised in the United States. A military force, at the command of Congress, can execute no laws, but such as the people perceive to be just and constitutional; for they will possess the power, and jealousy will instantly inspire the inclination, to resist the execution of a law which appears to them unjust and oppressive." Noah Webster, "An Examination into the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution" (1787) in Pamphlets on the Constitution of the United States (P. Ford, 1888).
 
 See here also federalist James Madison (the author of the 2nd. Amendment) note the armed populace advantage:
 
 "Besides the advantage of being armed, which the Americans possess over the people of almost every other nation. . . .Notwithstanding the military establishments in the several kingdoms of Europe, which are carried as far as the public resources will bear, the governments are afraid to trust the people with arms. . . ." James Madison, The Federalist Papers # 46, reprinted at pages 294-300 in The Federalist Papers, Mentor Books, 1969, edited by Clinton Rossiter. (Note: edited out are portions of Madison's address which further emphasis another key for him to preventing centralized federal tyranny-the residual authority of the states over the militias)
 
 Again, the reality of a pre-existing individual RKBA is critical to understanding where the 2nd. Amendment places the right. In addition to proclaiming the preference for militias over standing armies, the amendment was intended to deny Congress a monopoly over the true badges of liberty. The founders could have done so in one of two ways:
 
 1. They could have given concurrent power to the states to arm their militias, or
 2. They could have recognized and protected the established individual RKBA.
 
 The idea of the states holding concurrent power had been discussed during the original Constitutional debates. Consider Patrick Henry again, as he questioned the possibility of an implied concurrent power: 
 
 "May we not discipline and arm them, as well as Congress, if the power be concurrent? so that our militia shall have two sets of arms, double sets of regimentals, &c.; and thus, at a very great cost, we shall be doubly armed. The great object is, that every man be armed. But can the people afford to pay for double sets of arms, &c.? Every one Who is able may have a gun. But we have learned, by experience, that, necessary as it is to have arms, and though our Assembly has, by a succession of laws for many years, endeavored to have the militia completely armed, it is still far from being the case. When this power is given up to Congress without. limitation or bounds, how will your militia be afraid? You trust to chance; for sure I am that that nation which shall trust its liberties in other hands cannot long exist. If gentlemen are serious when they suppose a concurrent power, where can be the impolicy to amend it? Or, in other words, to say that Congress shall not arm or discipline them, till the states Shall have refused or neglected to do it? This is my object. I only wish to bring it to what they themselves say is implied. Implication is to be the foundation of our civil liberties; and when you speak of arming the militia by a concurrence of power, you use implication. But implication will not save you, when a strong army of veterans comes upon you. You would be laughed at by the whole world, for trusting your safety implicitly to implication." Patrick Henry Speech of June 14, 1778.
 
 Problems arise, however, from having concurrent authority. In the same speech Henry noted that if the powers are concurrent, then what would prevent Congress from claiming concurrent power to appoint officers? Concurrent power was the path of confusion, and I argue that to deny the monopoly to Congress the founders instead chose to recognize what they already knew existed-the individual RKBA.
 
 Other writers here have described the founders to be "wordsmiths." I don't disagree with that assumption. Had the founders desired to grant concurrent power to the states to arm their militias, then the Amendment would have read something like "the states shall have the power to arm their militias independent of the Congress." We know, however, that the Amendment reads "the right of the people." 
 
 Consider the advantages for a moment of this plain reading of this text-the individual citizen's RKBA. One the one hand, it does nothing to alter the efficiency of Congress' power to create a uniform militia system (and hopefully thereby rendering a standing army unnecessary), while on the other hand it insures Congress cannot remove the check (an armed populace) that Webster and others argued would be a sufficient defense against a federal tyrant. It's not a perfect solution by any means, but as Tench Coxe noted, it was the one which was chosen:
 
 "As civil rulers, not having their duty to the people duly before them, may attempt to tyrannize, and as the military forces which must be occasionally raised to defend our country, might pervert their power to the injury of their fellow citizens, the people are confirmed by the article in their right to keep and bear private arms." Tench Coxe, Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution. Published under the pseudonym, "A Pennsylvanian" in the Philadelphia Federal Gazette, June 18, 1789 at 2 Col. 1. (Emphasis added).
 
 ---
 
 "On every question of construction let us carry ourselves back to the time when the Constitution was adopted, recollect the spirit manifested in the debates, and instead of trying what meaning can be squeezed out of the text, or invented against it, conform to the probable one which was passed." Thomas Jefferson, The Complete Jefferson, p. 322 (1957) [Letter to William Johnson, June 12, 1823].
 
 "And that the said Constitution be never construed to authorize Congress to infringe the just liberty of the Press, or the rights of Conscience; or to prevent the people of the United States, who are peaceable citizens, from keeping their own arms. . . ." Samuel Adams, Debates & Proceedings in the Convention of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, 86-87 (February 6, 1788).
